Also let \(X=[1\:\:\:1\:\:\:1]^T\) and \(Y=[Y_1\:\:\:Y_2\:\:\:Y_3]^T\) where \((Y_1,Y_2,Y_3)=\)({Y_1},{Y_2},{Y_3})

What is the angle between \(RX\) and \(RY\) in radians?

name.text: Angular momentum of a bead on a hoop

questiontext.text:
Consider a bead of mass \(m\)={m}kg constrained to move on a rotating hoop as shown in the figure below. The hoop is rotating about a vertical axis and the plane of the hoop is vertical. A frame \(\mathbf{e}\) that is fixed with respect to the earth has its origin coinciding with that of the origin of the hoop and the \(\mathbf{e}_3\) axis pointing vertically upwards. A frame \(\mathbf{c}\) is fixed to the hoop in such a way that its origin coincides with the centre of hoop and the \(\mathbf{c}_3\) axis aligns with the \(\mathbf{e}_3\) axis and the \(\mathbf{c}_1\) axis is perpendicular to the plane of the hoop. The frame \(\mathbf{b}\) is fixed to the bead in such a way that its origin coincides with the centre of hoop and the \(\mathbf{b}_1\) axis aligns with the \(\mathbf{c}_1\) axis and the \(\mathbf{b}_2\) axis aligns along the bead.
 
 
 
Let the radius of the hoop be denoted by \(r\)={r} m and \(\phi=\)={phi}, \(\dot{\phi}=\)={dphi} rad/s, and the hoop is rotating about the vertical axis at a rate equal to {dtheta} rad/s. 

Let \(\pi_p\) denote the angular momentum of the bead as expressed in the \(\mathbf{e}\) frame.
The magnitude of this \(||\pi_p||\) is given by
Find \( \alpha\) in the following partial fraction expansion \( \frac{1}{s^2+{omega}^2}=\frac{i\alpha}{s+i{omega}}-\frac{i\bar{\alpha}}{s-i{omega}} \)

name.text: Description of Motion in Moving Frames

questiontext.text: Consider the figure and answer \( R=\begin{bmatrix} \cos{\theta} & -\sin{\theta} & 0\\ \sin{\theta} & \cos{\theta} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{bmatrix} \)

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \( \left[\begin{matrix}0 & 1\\- \omega_{n}^{2} & -2\zeta \omega_n\end{matrix}\right] \) when \( 0 < \zeta < 1\) using sympy and type your answer in the text box below using LaTeX.

Consider the lumped parameter approximate model of a very lightly damped coupled translational system that is shown in the figure below:

Show that the equations of motion of the system for small amplitude motion are given by

\( \begin{align} m_1\ddot{x}_1&=-k_1(x_1-x_2)+u,\\ m_2\ddot{x}_2&=-k_1(x_2-x_1)-k_2(x_2-x_3)\\ m_3\ddot{x}_3&=-k_2(x_3-x_2) \end{align}. \)

Show that the above equations take the form:

\( \begin{align} M\ddot{X}+KX&=Fu \end{align} \)

where

\( \begin{align} X=\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\\x_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix}m_1 & 0 &0 \\0 & m_2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & m_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: K=\begin{bmatrix} k_1 & -k_1 & 0\\ -k_1 & (k_1+k_2) & -k_2\\ 0 & -k_2 & k_3 \end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: F=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\0\end{bmatrix} \end{align} \)

Answer the following:
  1. Show that the space of \(3 \times 3\) skew-symmetric matrices can be identified with \(\mathbb{R}^3\) using the identification: \(X \mapsto \widehat{X}\) explicitly given by
    \(\begin{align} \widehat{X}=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & -X_3 & X_2 \\ X_3 & 0 & -X_1 \\ -X_2 & X_1 & 0\end{array}\right], \end{align}\) for \(X =[X_1\:\:\:X_2\:\:\:X_3]^T\).
  2. For \(X,Y \in \mathbb{R}^3\) and \(R\in SO(3)\) show that the hat map above is related to the cross product by \(\mathbb{R}^3\) as \(\begin{align} X \times Y&=\widehat{X}Y, \end{align}\)
  3. Prove the following identities
    \(\begin{align} R(X\times Y)&=(RX)\times (RY),\\ \widehat{RX}&=R\widehat{X}R^T,\\  \widehat{X}^2&=XX^T-||X||^2I_{3\times 3}. \end{align}\)
  4. What are the physical implications of \(R(X\times Y)=(RX)\times (RY)\)
Find the roots of the characteristic polynomial of a second order spring mass damper system that is given by \(\Delta(s)=(s^2+2\zeta\omega_n s+\omega_n^2)\)

Consider the small amplitude motion of the interconnected spring mass system shown below.


Let \(u(t)\equiv 0\) and assume that the friction between the rollers and the floor are negligibly small. 

Choose the incorrect statements.

answer.text:
The system can be modelled by the matrix differential equation
\(M\ddot{x}+Kx=0\)
where 
\(\begin{align*}
X=\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\\x_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\:
M=\begin{bmatrix}m_1 & 0 &0 \\0 & m_2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & m_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\:
K=\begin{bmatrix}
k_1 & -k_1 & 0\\ -k_1 & (k_1+k_2) & -k_2\\ 0 & -k_2 & k_2
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}\)

The system can not be written down as a first order matrix ODE of the form

\(\dot{Y}=AY\)
The total momentum of the system is conserved

questiontext.text:
Consider a collection of interacting set of particles \(P_1,P_2,\cdots,P_n\). The mass of a particle \(P_i\) is denoted by \(m_i\) and the resultant effect it feels due to external interactions is denoted by \(f^e_i\). Let \(M=\sum_{i=1}^nm_i\), \(p=\sum_{i}^nm_i\dot{x}_i\), \(f^e=\sum_{i=1}^nf^e_i\), \(M\bar{x}=\sum_{i=1}^nm_ix_i\), \(\pi=\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-o)\times m_i\dot{x}_i\)


Which of the following statements are incorrect? (choose all incorrect answers)

answer.text: If the moments are taken about the center of mass then \(\begin{align}\dot{\pi}=\tau^e\end{align}\)

questiontext.text:

Copy and paste your python code that generates an animation and upload the figure

name.text: Using Plotly plot an orthonormal frame

questiontext.text:
This is Q1 in this Assignment.

Copy and paste the python code that will plot an orthonormal frame using the package Plotly

Also upload the figure that you generated.

Which of the following are a consequence of the principle of conservation of linear momentum.

  1. The three laws of motion as stated by Newton.
  2. Every inertial observer agrees that the center of mass of a water bubble in outer space moves in a straight line or is at rest
  3. Every inertial observer will agree that pairwise particle interactions are equal and opposite and act along the straight line joining the two particles.
  4. Every inertial observer will agree that the angular momentum of a set of isolated particles about the center of mass of the particles is conserved.

Which of the following are a consequence of the principle of conservation of linear momentum.

  1. Every inertial observer agrees that the center of mass of a water bubble in outer space moves in a straight line or is at rest
  2. The three laws of motion as stated by Newton.
  3. Every inertial observer will agree that the angular momentum of a set of isolated particles about the center of mass of the particles is conserved.
  4. Every inertial observer will agree that pairwise particle interactions are equal and opposite and act along the straight line joining the two particles.
  5. Every inertial observer will agree that the rate of change of the angular momentum of a set of isolated particles about the center of mass of the particles is equal to the resultant of the external moments of the set of particles about the center of mass.

In Galilean mechanics it is assumed that

  1. time is independent of space.
  2. time depends on space.
  3. time behaves the same forward as well as backwards.
  4. the difference in time between any two particular instants is not the same.
  5. space is the same in every direction.
  6. space is not the same in every direction.
  7. the distance between any two particular points in space is the same.
  8. the distance between any two particular points in space is not the same.
  9. there are no gaps in time and no holes in space.
  10. space is not homogenous.


Select the true statement/s.

answer.text: Not all of the statements (1), (3), (5), (7), and (9) are true.

questiontext.text:
Consider the following statements about inertial observers.

  1. They all agree on Galilean space-time assumptions.
  2. They are either stationary or are moving with constant relative velocity (and without rotation) with respect to each other.
  3. If they are parallel to each other they all agree on the acceleration of a particle.
  4. They all agree on the magnitude of the mutual interaction between any two particles.
  5. If they are parallel to each other they all agree on the total linear momentum of an isolated set of particles.


Which of the following is true?

answer.text: All of the statements above are true.

questiontext.text:
Consider the following statements about inertial observers.

  1. They all agree on Galilean space-time assumptions.
  2. They are either stationary or are moving with constant relative velocity (and without rotation) with respect to each other.
  3. They all agree on the magnitude of the mutual interaction between any two particles.
  4. If they are parallel to each other they all agree on the total linear momentum of an isolated set of particles.
  5. If they are parallel to each other they all agree on the acceleration of a particle.


Which of the following is true?

answer.text: All of the statements above are true.

questiontext.text: If an inertial observer \(\mathbf {e}\) sees that an object moving in a straight line at constant acceleration all other inertial observers will also observe the particle to be moving in a straight line at constant acceleration.

name.text: Straight Line Motion - Constant Acceleration and Velocity

questiontext.text:
1. If an inertial observer \(\mathbf {e}\) sees that an object is moving in a straight line at constant acceleration all other inertial observers will also observe that the particle is moving in a straight line at constant acceleration.
  2. If an inertial observer \(\mathbf {e}\) sees that an object is moving in a straight line at constant velocity all other inertial observers will also observe that the particle is moving in a straight line at constant acceleration.

Only one of the above statements are true.

If an inertial observer \(\mathbf {e}\) sees that an object moving in a straight line at constant velocity all other inertial observers will also observe the particle to be moving in a straight line at constant velocity.

Let \(R_i(\theta_j)\) denote a rotation about the \(i^{\mathrm{th}}\) axis by an angle \(\theta_j\). Also let \(X=[{X_1}\:\:\:{X_2}\:\:\:{X_3}]^T\) and \(Y=[{Y_1}\:\:\:{Y_2}\:\:\:{Y_3}]^T\).

Let \(R=R_1(\theta_1)R_3(\theta_3)\) where \(\theta_1\)={theta_1} and \(\theta_3\)={theta_3}

Let \(\mathbf {e}\) and \(\mathbf {b}\) be two orthonormal frames with coinciding origin. They are moving relatively to each other at all time instances. Let \(R(t)\in SO(3)\) be such that \(\mathbf {b}(t) =\mathbf {e}R(t)\) and \(\widehat {\Omega }=R^T\dot {R}\).
Which of the following are true statements.

  1. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\Omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\Omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {b}\).
  2. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\Omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\Omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {e}\).
  3. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {e}\) where \(\widehat {\omega }=R\widehat {\Omega }R^T\).
  4. \(\Omega \) is the angular velocity of the frame \(\mathbf {b}\) with respect to the frame \(\mathbf {e}\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {b}\).

Let \(\mathbf {e}\) and \(\mathbf {b}\) be two orthonormal frames with coinciding origin. They are moving relatively to each other at all time instances. Let \(R(t)\in SO(3)\) be such that \(\mathbf {b}(t) =\mathbf {e}R(t)\) and \(\widehat {\Omega }=R^T\dot {R}\).
Which of the following are true statements.

  1. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\Omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\Omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {b}\).
  2. \(\Omega \) is the angular velocity of the frame \(\mathbf {b}\) with respect to the frame \(\mathbf {e}\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {b}\).
  3. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {e}\) where \(\widehat {\omega }=R\widehat {\Omega }R^T\).
  4. \(R\) is an instantaneous rotation about the axis \(\Omega \) at a rate of rotation equal to \(||\Omega ||\) as viewed in the frame \(\mathbf {e}\).

Consider an arbitrary \(R\in SO(3)\) and state which of the following statements are true.

  1. If \(a\) represents some physical quantity that is represented as a directed line segment (such as position, angular momentum, force etc.) in \(\mathbf {e}\) then the first element of the \(3\times 1\) matrix \(R^Ta\) is the component of that quantity along the \(\mathbf {b}_1\) axis where \(\mathbf {b}=\mathbf {e}R\).
  2. Consider a set of points \(\{P_1,P_2,\cdots ,P_n\}\) in space and let \(x_i\) denote the representation of the \(i^{\mathrm {th}}\) point \(P_i\) in some orthonormal frame \(\mathbf {e}\) with origin \(O\). For some \(R\in SO(3)\) let \(P_{i_R}\) be the point with representation \(Rx_i\) in the \(\mathbf {e}\)-frame. Then the distance between \(P_{i_R}\) and \(P_{j_R}\) is equal to the distance between \(P_{i}\) and \(P_{j}\) and the angle between \(OP_{i_R}\) and \(OP_{j_R}\) is equal to the angle between \(OP_{i}\) and \(OP_{j}\) for all \(i,j\in \{1,2,\cdots ,n\}\).
  3. \(R_1R_2=R_2R_1\) for any \(R_1,R_2\in SO(3)\) .
  4. Every \(R\) can be uniquely expressed using \(3-1-3\) Euler Angles

answer.text: All of the above statements are true.
None of the above statements are true.

questiontext.text:
Consider an arbitrary \(R\in SO(3)\) and state which of the following statements are true.

  1. If \(a\) represents some physical quantity that is represented as a directed line segment (such as position, angular momentum, force etc.) in \(\mathbf {e}\) then the first element of the \(3\times 1\) matrix \(R^Ta\) is the component of that quantity along the \(\mathbf {b}_1\) axis where \(\mathbf {b}=\mathbf {e}R\).
  2. Consider a set of points \(\{P_1,P_2,\cdots ,P_n\}\) in space and let \(x_i\) denote the representation of the \(i^{\mathrm {th}}\) point \(P_i\) in some orthonormal frame \(\mathbf {e}\) with origin \(O\). For some \(R\in SO(3)\) let \(P_{i_R}\) be the point with representation \(Rx_i\) in the \(\mathbf {e}\)-frame. Then the distance between \(P_{i_R}\) and \(P_{j_R}\) is equal to the distance between \(P_{i}\) and \(P_{j}\) and the angle between \(OP_{i_R}\) and \(OP_{j_R}\) is equal to the angle between \(OP_{i}\) and \(OP_{j}\) for all \(i,j\in \{1,2,\cdots ,n\}\).
  3. \(R_1R_2=R_2R_1\) for any \(R_1,R_2\in SO(3)\) .
  4. The \(3-1-3\) Euler Angle representation of\(R\in SO(3)\) is not globally defined.

answer.text: All of the above statements are true.
None of the above statements are true.

questiontext.text:
State which of the following statements are true.

  1. For every \(R\in SO(3)\) there exists a \(3\times 1\) matrix \(V\) such that \(RV=V\).
  2. There can exist a \(R\in SO(3)\) such that one of its eigenvalues has magnitude greater than one.
  3. The eigenvalues of any \(R\in SO(3)\) are of the form \(\{1,e^{i\theta },e^{-i\theta }\}\).
  4. The space of \(SO(3)\) is identical to the unit solid sphere in \(\mathbb {R}^3\) with the points on the surface that are diametrically opposite to each other identified.
  5. The statement (3) implies (1) and (4).

answer.text: All of the above statements are true.

questiontext.text:
State which of the following statements are true.

  1. For every \(R\in SO(3)\) there exists a \(3\times 1\) matrix \(V\) such that \(RV=V\).
  2. If one of the eigenvalues of \(R\in SO(3)\) is \(e^{i\theta}\) and \(U\) is the eigenvector of \(R\) that corresponds to the eigenvalue 1 then \(R\) is a rotation about \(U\) by an angle equal to \(\theta\).
  3. There can exist a \(R\in SO(3)\) such that one of its eigenvalues has magnitude greater than one.
  4. The eigenvalues of any \(R\in SO(3)\) are of the form \(\{1,e^{i\theta },e^{-i\theta }\}\).
  5. The space of \(SO(3)\) is identical to the unit solid sphere in \(\mathbb {R}^3\) with the points on the surface that are diametrically opposite to each other identified.
  6. The statement (4) implies (1) and (5).

answer.text: All of the above statements are true.

questiontext.text:
Let \(\mathbf {e}\) and \(\mathbf {b}\) be two orthonormal frames with coinciding origin. They are moving relatively to each other at all time instances. Let \(R(t)\in SO(3)\) be such that \(\mathbf {b}(t) =\mathbf {e}R(t)\) and \(\widehat {\Omega }=R^T\dot {R}\). Which of the following are true statements.

  1. \(R(t)\) is a symmetric \(3\times 3\) matrix with \(\mathrm {det}\left (R(t)\right )=1\).
  2. \(\widehat {\Omega }\) is a skew-symmetric \(3\times 3\) matrix.
  3. The space \(SO(3)\) is a 3-dimensional vector space.
  4. The space of all possible \(\widehat {\Omega }\) is a 3-dimensional vector space.

Which of the following are true statements about \(R\in SO(3)\).

  1. \(R=\exp {\left (\widehat {\Omega }\right )}\) for some \(\Omega \in \mathbb {R}^3\).
  2. \(R=I_{3\times 3}+2q_0\widehat {w}+2\widehat {w}^2\) for \(q_0\in \mathbb {R}\) and \(w\in \mathbb {R}^3\) such that \(q_0^2+||w||^2=1\).
  3. Every \(R\in SO(3)\) can be identified with two points on \(\mathbb {S}^3\), the surface of the unit sphere in \(\mathbb {R}^4\).

Which of the following are true statements about \(R\in SO(3)\).

  1. \(R=\exp {\left (\widehat {\Omega }\right )}\) for some \(\Omega \in \mathbb {R}^3\).
  2. \(R=I_{3\times 3}+2q_0\widehat {w}+2\widehat {w}^2\) for \(q_0\in \mathbb {R}\) and \(w\in \mathbb {R}^3\) such that \(q_0^2+||w||^2=1\).
  3. Every \(R\in SO(3)\) can be identified with two anti-podal points on \(\mathbb {S}^3\), the surface of the unit sphere in \(\mathbb {R}^4\).
  4. Ifthe eigenvalues of \(R\in SO(3)\) are \(\{1,e^{i\theta},e^{-i\theta}\}\) then \(R=I_{3\times 3}+\sin{\theta}\,\widehat {n}+(1-\cos{\theta})\,\widehat {n}^2\) where \(Rn=n\) and \(||n||=1\).

name.text: Frequency of Oscillation of a SMD

questiontext.text:
Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

If \(M=\){M}, \(K=\){K} and \(\zeta=\){zeta}, and the system is acted upon by an impulsive force find the frequency of oscillation of the system in rad/s.

Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

Find the resonant amplitude of the Spring Mass Damper system shown above where \(M=\){M} kg, \(K=\){K} N/m and \(\zeta=\){zeta} and the amplitude of the sinusoidal forcing is \(F_0=\){F0} N.

Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

Find the resonant frequency \(\omega_r\) of the Spring Mass Damper system shown above where \(M=\){M} kg, \(K=\){K} N/m and \(\zeta=\){zeta}

Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

Let \( \omega_n^2\triangleq \frac{K}{M},\:\:\:\:2\zeta\omega_n=\frac{C}{M} \).

Answer the following questions.

name.text: Dynamic System Form of the SMD

questiontext.text:
Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

Let \( \omega_n^2\triangleq \frac{K}{M},\:\:\:\:2\zeta\omega_n=\frac{C}{M} \).

Then Newton's equations for the mass \(M\) for small amplitude motion is give by:

\(\ddot{x}+2\zeta\omega_n\dot{x}+\omega_n^2x=\frac{1}{M}F\)

  • Write down the above system equations in the controlled dynamic system form:

\( \dot{X}=AX+Bu \)

  • Show that the solution of the above equation is explicitly given by \( X(t)=e^{At}X(0)+\int_0^te^{A(t-\tau)}Bu(\tau)\,d\tau \)

graderinfo.text:
Let\( X_1\triangleq x\) and \(X_2\triangleq \dot{x}\). Then we can write the second order ODE \(\ddot{x}+\omega_n^2x=0\) as the following coupled set of first order ODEs.

\begin{align} \dot{X}_1&=X_2,\\ \dot{X}_2 &=-\omega_n^2\,X_1. \end{align} This we can write down as the following first order matrix ODE \begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} \dot{X}_1\\ \dot{X}_2 \end{bmatrix}&= \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -\omega_n^2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}}_{A} \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} {X}_1\\ {X}_2 \end{bmatrix}}_{X}. \end{align} \begin{align} \dot{X}=AX \end{align} This is typically referred to as the dynamic systems form of the system. Re-writing this we have the sequence of steps \begin{align} \dot{X}-AX &=0\\ e^{-At}\dot{X}-e^{-At}AX &=0\\ \dfrac{d}{dt}e^{-At}X&=0\\ \int_0^t\dfrac{d}{dt}e^{-At}X&=0\\ e^{-At}X(t)-X(0)&=0. \end{align} Which finally gives \begin{align} X(t)&=e^{At}X(0). \end{align} This is called the matrix exponential solution of the linear dynamic system \(\dot{X}=AX\).

Consider the spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

The spring mass damper system shown above is influenced by a sinusoidal force of the form \( \begin{align} F(t)=F_0\,\cos{(\omega t)} \end{align} \).

If the system is very lightly damped it can beshown that the steady state response of the system is given by \( \begin{align} x_{ss}(t)=\chi(\omega)\,F_0\,\cos(\omega t +\phi(\omega)), \end{align} \) where \( \begin{align} \chi(\omega)=\frac{1/M}{\sqrt{(\omega_n^2-\omega^2)^2+4\zeta^2\omega^2\omega_n^2}} \end{align} \) and \( \begin{align} \phi(\omega)=\arctan{\left(\frac{2\zeta\omega\omega_n}{\omega_n^2-\omega^2}\right)}. \end{align} \)

Answer the following:

  • Attach a figure of the frequency response of the system for a suitable choice of system parameters
  • Copy and paste the Python code that will re-produce the frequency response.

name.text: Unforced overdamped response of a SMD

questiontext.text: Show that when the forcing \(f(t)\equiv 0\) and \( \zeta > 1\) the poles of the system \(-\lambda_1, -\lambda_2\) are given by \( \begin{align} -\lambda_1, -\lambda_2=\omega_n(-\zeta \pm \sqrt{1-\zeta^2}), \end{align} \) and that the solution takes the form \( \begin{align} \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1(t) \\ x_2(t)\end{array} \right]= \left[\begin{array}{c}c_{11}\,e^{-\lambda_1 t}+c_{12} \,e^{-\lambda_2 t} \\ -\lambda_1c_{11}\,e^{-\lambda_1 t}-\lambda_2c_{12}\,e^{-\lambda_2 t} \end{array} \right]. \end{align} \)

name.text: Unforced undamped response of a SMD

questiontext.text: Show that when the forcing \(f(t)\equiv 0\) and the damping is negligibly small the poles of the system \(-\lambda_1, -\lambda_2\) are approximately given by \( \begin{align} -\lambda_1, -\lambda_2=\pm i\omega_n, \end{align} \) and that the corresponding solution takes the form \( \begin{align} \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1(t) \\ x_2(t)\end{array} \right]= \left[\begin{array}{c}c_{11}\,\sin{\omega_n t}+ c_{12}\,\cos{\omega_n t}\\ c_{21}\,\sin{\omega_n t}+ c_{22}\,\cos{\omega_n t} \end{array} \right]. \end{align} \)

name.text: Unforced underdamped response of a SMD

questiontext.text: Show that when the forcing \(f(t)\equiv 0\) and \(0 < \zeta < 1\) the poles of the system \(-\lambda_1, -\lambda_2\) are approximately given by \( \begin{align} -\lambda_1, -\lambda_2=-\zeta \omega_n\pm i\omega_d, \end{align} \) where \(\omega_d=\omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}\) and that the solution takes the form \( \begin{align} \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1(t) \\ x_2(t)\end{array} \right]= \left[\begin{array}{c}e^{-\zeta\omega_n t}(c_{11}\,\sin{\omega_d t}+ c_{12}\,\cos{\omega_d t})\\ e^{-\zeta\omega_n t}(c_{21}\,\sin{\omega_d t}+ c_{22}\,\cos{\omega_d t}) \end{array} \right]. \end{align} \)

name.text: 2DOF Rotational and Translational System - Resonant Frequency

questiontext.text:
Consider the coupled torsional plus translational system shown in the figure below:

The equations of motion of the system take the form \( \begin{align} M\ddot{Y}+C\dot{Y}+KY=F(t), \end{align} \)

where \( \begin{align} Y(t)=\begin{bmatrix} x(t)\\ \theta (t)\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: F(t)=f(t)\begin{bmatrix}1\\ c\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix} m & 0\\0 & I\end{bmatrix}, \end{align} \) \( \begin{align} C=\begin{bmatrix} 2b & -b(l_2-l_1)\\ -b(l_2-l_1) & b(l_1^2+l_2^2)\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: K=\begin{bmatrix} 2k & -k(l_2-l_1)\\ -k(l_2-l_1) & k(l_1^2+l_2^2)\end{bmatrix} \end{align} \)

Consider the case where the damping in the system is very small.

Find the largest driving frequency, \(\omega\) rad/s, at which the system exhibits violent vibrations when \(m=\){m}kg, \(I=\){II}\(kgm^2\), \(k=\){k}N/m, \(l_2=(l+\epsilon)\)m,\(l_1=(l-\epsilon)\)m, \(\epsilon=0.01\times l\)m and \(l=\){l} m.

Consider the coupled translational vibratory system shown in the figure below:

The equations of motion of the system take the form \(\begin{align} M\ddot{X}+C\dot{X}+KX&=0 \end{align} \)

where \( \begin{align} X=\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix}m & 0\\0 & m\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: F=\begin{bmatrix}F_1\\ F_2\end{bmatrix} \end{align} \)

\( \begin{align} K=\begin{bmatrix}k_1+k_2 & -k_2\\ -k_2 & k_2+k_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: C=\begin{bmatrix}c_1+c_2 & -c_2\\ -c_2 & c_2+c_3\end{bmatrix},\end{align} \)

Consider the case where \(F_2(t)\equiv 0\), \(F_1(t)=f_0\cos{\omega t}\) and the damping in the system is very small.

Find the largest driving frequency, \(\omega\) rad/s, at which the system exhibits violent vibrations when \(m_1=\){m_1}kg, \(m_2=\){m_2}kg, \(k_1=\){k_1}N/m, \(k_2=\){k_2}N/m, \(k_3=\){k_3}N/m.

Consider the coupled spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

The equations of motion of the system are given by \( \begin{align} M\ddot{X}+C\dot{X}+KX=F(t). \end{align} \)

where \( \begin{align} X(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\ x_2(t)\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\:F(t)=\begin{bmatrix}f_1(t)\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix} m_1 & 0\\0 & m_2\end{bmatrix} ,\:\:\:\: C=\begin{bmatrix} (c_1+c_2) & -c_2\\-c_2 & c_2\end{bmatrix} \:\:\:\: K=\begin{bmatrix} (k_1+k_2) & -k_2\\-k_2 & k_2\end{bmatrix}. \end{align} \)

Consider the case where the damping in the system is very small.

Find the largest driving frequency, \(\omega\) rad/s, at which the system exhibits violent vibrations when \(m_1=\){m_1}kg, \(m_2=\){m_2}kg, \(k_1=\){k_1}N/m, \(k_2=\){k_2}N/m.

Consider the coupled 3-DOF system shown above where \(u(t)=u_0\cos{\omega t}\) and \(m_1=\){m_1}kg, \(m_2=\){m_2}kg, \(m_3=\){m_3}kg, \(k_1=\){k_1}N/m, \(k_2=\){k_2}N/m, \(k_3=\){k_3}N/m.

Find the largest resonance frequency of the system:

Answer the following in the space provided:

  • Type (using LaTeX) the expression for the frequency response of the mass \(m_1\) in the space below
  • Attach the Python generated figure of the frequency response of the mass \(m_1\) to the answer
  • Cut and paste the Python code that re-produces your answer.

Consider the coupled translational vibratory system shown in the figure below:

The equations of motion of the system take the form \(\begin{align} M\ddot{X}+C\dot{X}+KX&=0 \end{align} \)

where \( \begin{align} X=\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix}m & 0\\0 & m\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: F=\begin{bmatrix}F_1\\ F_2\end{bmatrix} \end{align} \)

\( \begin{align} K=\begin{bmatrix}k_1+k_2 & -k_2\\ -k_2 & k_2+k_3\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: C=\begin{bmatrix}c_1+c_2 & -c_2\\ -c_2 & c_2+c_3\end{bmatrix},\end{align} \)

Consider the lumped parameter approximate model of a very lightly damped coupled translational system that is shown in the figure below:

Show that the equations of motion of the system for small amplitude motion are given by

\( \begin{align} m_1\ddot{x}_1&=-k_1(x_1-x_2)+u,\\ m_2\ddot{x}_2&=-k_1(x_2-x_1)-k_2(x_2-x_3)\\ m_3\ddot{x}_3&=-k_2(x_3-x_2) \end{align}. \)

where

Consider the coupled spring mass damper system shown in the figure below:

The equations of motion of the system are given by \( \begin{align} M\ddot{X}+C\dot{X}+KX=F(t). \end{align} \)

where \( \begin{align} X(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\ x_2(t)\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\:f(t)=\begin{bmatrix}f_1(t)\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\:\:\:\: M=\begin{bmatrix} m_1 & 0\\0 & m_2\end{bmatrix} ,\:\:\:\: C=\begin{bmatrix} (c_1+c_2) & -c_2\\-c_2 & c_2\end{bmatrix} \:\:\:\: K=\begin{bmatrix} (k_1+k_2) & -k_2\\-k_2 & k_2\end{bmatrix}. \end{align} \)

Consider the case where the damping is very low and the forcing is sinusoidal.

That is let \(C\approx 0_{2\times 2}\) and \(f_1(t)=f_0\cos{\omega t}\). Also let \( \begin{align} \omega_{n1}^2=\frac{k_1}{m_1},\:\:\:\omega_{n2}^2=\frac{k_2}{m_2}, \:\:\:\mu=\frac{m_2}{m_1},\:\:\:\alpha=\frac{\omega_{n_2}^2}{\omega_{n_1}^2} \end{align} \)

name.text: Deriving Purely Rotating Rigid Body Equations in a body frame

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of particles interacting in such a way that they are rigid with respect to each other and point \(O'\) in the body is fixed with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\). Let \(\mathbf{b}\) be a frame that is fixed to the set of particle with the origin coinciding with the pivot point \(O'\).

Let \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) in the \(\mathbf{e}\) frame, \(M\) be the total mass of the particles, \(\bar{X}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the particles in the \(\mathbf{b}\) frame, \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\), \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}\), \(\omega=R\Omega\).

Also let \(T_e\) be the, \(\mathbf{b}\) frame representation of the, resultant of the moment of the external forces acting on the particles about the point \(O'\).

Show that the purely rotating rigid body equations are given by:

\( \begin{align} \dot{R}&=\widehat{\omega}R,\\ \dot{\pi}&=\tau_e \end{align} \)

with

\(\begin{align} \omega &=(R\mathbb{I}^{-1}R^T)\pi. \end{align} \)

in the spatial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) and

\( \begin{align*} \dot{R}&=R\widehat{\Omega},\\ \mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}&=\mathbb{I}\Omega \times {\Omega}+T^e. \end{align*} \)

in the body frame \(\mathbf{b}\)

where

\( \begin{align} \mathbb{I}=-\sum_{i}m_i\widehat{X}_i^2\end{align} \)

is the moment of inertia tensor of the body with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\).

generalfeedback.text: Setting \(\dot{o}\equiv 0\) and hence noting that \(p\equiv M\,\omega \times \bar{x}'\) reduces the general equations to these.

name.text: Deriving Rigid Body Equations in a body frame

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of particles interacting in such a way that they are rigid with respect to each other. Let \(\mathbf{b}\) be a frame that is fixed to the set of particle and \(\mathbf{e}\) be an inertial frame. Denote by \(O'\) the origin of the\(\mathbf{b}\) frame

Let \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) in the \(\mathbf{e}\) frame, \(M\) be the total mass of the particles, \(\bar{X}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the particles in the \(\mathbf{b}\) frame, \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\), \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}\), \(\omega=R\Omega\).

Also let \(F_e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles and \(T_e\) be the resultant of the moment of the external forces acting on the particles about the point \(O'\). Both \(F_e\) and \(T_e\) are \(\mathbf{b}\) frame representations

Show that the rigid body equations are given by:

\( \begin{align*} \dot{R}&=R\widehat{\Omega},\\ MR^T\ddot{o}-M\,\widehat{\bar{X}}\dot{\Omega}& = -M\,\widehat{\Omega}^2(t) \bar{X} + F^e,\\ \mathbb{I}_c\dot{\Omega}&=\mathbb{I}_c\Omega \times {\Omega}+T^e_c. \end{align*} \)

where

\( \begin{align} \mathbb{I}_c=-\underbrace{\sum_{i}m_i\widehat{X}_i^2}_{\mathbb{I}}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2 \end{align} \)

is the moment of inertia tensor of the body with respect to a frame that is parallel to \(\mathbf{b}\) and origin coinciding with the center of mass of the body.

generalfeedback.text:
We have shown in the previous questions that the following are all equivalent expressions for the rate of change of total angular momentum of the body about the origin of the the body frame \(O'\):

  1. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( -M\dot{o}\times \dot{\bar{x}}+\tau_e \)

  2. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( \omega \times (\bar{x}-o)\times p+\tau_e \)

  3. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega \times {\bar{X}}+T_e \)

  4. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \(\left(\mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}-\mathbb{I}{\Omega}\times \Omega-MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega\times \bar{X} +M\bar{X}\times R^T\ddot{o}\right)\)

    where \(\mathbb{I} \) is the moment of inertia tensor of the set of particles about \(O'\)

  5. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times R^T\dot{\bar{x}}+T_e \)

From 3. and 4. we have:

\( \left(\mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}-\mathbb{I}{\Omega}\times \Omega-MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega\times \bar{X} +M\bar{X}\times R^T\ddot{o}\right)=-MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega \times {\bar{X}}+T_e \)

where \(\mathbb{I} \) is the moment of inertia tensor of the set of particles about \(O'\).

Thus we have:

\( \mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}-\mathbb{I}{\Omega}\times \Omega+M\bar{X}\times R^T\ddot{o}=T^e \)

On the other hand from Newtons' equations for the center of mass we have:

\begin{align} MR^T\ddot{o}+\left(M\,\left(\widehat{\Omega}^2(t) +\dot{\widehat{\Omega}}\right)\bar{X}\right)&= F^e. \end{align}

Thus we have

\begin{align} M\bar{X}\times R^T\ddot{o}+\left(M\,\left(\widehat{\bar{X}}\widehat{\Omega}^2(t) +\widehat{\bar{X}}\dot{\widehat{\Omega}}\right)\bar{X}\right)&= \bar{X}\times F^e. \end{align}

Substituting this in the equation before we have

\( \mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}-\mathbb{I}{\Omega}\times \Omega-\left(M\,\left(\widehat{\bar{X}}\widehat{\Omega}^2(t) +\widehat{\bar{X}}\dot{\widehat{\Omega}}\right)\bar{X}\right)=-\bar{X}\times F^e+T^e \)

Thus using the properties of the corss product and re-arranging the terms we have that the above equation can be written down as:

\( \begin{align*} \dot{R}&=R\widehat{\Omega},\\ MR^T\ddot{o}-M\,\widehat{\bar{X}}\dot{\Omega}& = -M\,\widehat{\Omega}^2(t) \bar{X} + F^e,\\ \mathbb{I}_c\dot{\Omega}&=\mathbb{I}_c\Omega \times {\Omega}+T^e_c. \end{align*} \)

where \(T^e_c=-\bar{X}\times F^e+T^e \) and

\( \begin{align} \mathbb{I}_c=-\underbrace{\sum_{i}m_i\widehat{X}_i^2}_{\mathbb{I}}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2 \end{align} \)

name.text: Deriving Rigid Body Equations in spatial frame

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of particles interacting in such a way that they are rigid with respect to each other. Let \(\mathbf{b}\) be a frame that is fixed to the set of particle and \(\mathbf{e}\) be an inertial frame. Denote by \(O'\) the origin of the\(\mathbf{b}\) frame

Let \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) in the \(\mathbf{e}\) frame, \(M\) be the total mass of the particles, \(\bar{x}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the particles in the \(\mathbf{e}\) frame, \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\), \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}\), \(\omega=R\Omega\) and \(\bar{x}'=(\bar{x}-o)\).

Also let \( p\) be the total linear momentum of the particle, \(\pi\) be the total angular momenum of the set of particle about \(O'\), \(f_e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles, \(\tau_e\) be the resultant of the moment of the external forces acting on the particles about the point \(O'\). All \(p,\pi,f_e,\tau_e\) are \(\mathbf{e}\) frame representations

Show that the rigid body equations are given by:

\( \begin{align} \dot{o}&=\frac{1}{M}p-\omega \times \bar{x}',\\ \dot{R}&=\widehat{\omega}R,\\ \dot{p}&=f^e,\\ \dot{\pi}&=\omega \times \bar{x}'\times p+\tau_e \end{align} \)

with

\(\begin{align} \omega &=(\mathbb{I}_c^R)^{-1}\left(\pi-\bar{x}'\times p\right). \end{align} \)

where

\( \begin{align} \mathbb{I}_c=-\underbrace{\sum_{i}m_i\widehat{X}_i^2}_{\mathbb{I}}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2 \end{align} \)

\(\mathbb{I}_c \) is the moment of inertia tensor of the body with respect to a frame that is parallel to \(\mathbf{b}\) and origin coinciding with the center of mass of the object.

generalfeedback.text:
Let \(\bar{x}'\triangleq (\bar{x}-o)=R\bar{X}\). Differentiating this expression gives

\(\begin{align} \dot{\bar{x}}'&=R(\Omega \times \bar{X})=\omega \times \bar{x}'. \end{align} \)

Then the fact that \(p=M\dot{\bar{x}}\) gives

\( \begin{align} \dot{\pi}&=-M\dot{o}\times \dot{\bar{x}}+\tau_e=M\dot{\bar{x}}'\times \dot{\bar{x}}+\tau_e=\omega \times \bar{x}'\times p+\tau_e \end{align} \)

We also saw that the rigid body kinematic equations are given by \(M\dot{o}=p-M\omega \times \bar{x}'\) and \(\dot{R}=\widehat{\omega}R\)

name.text: Different forms of Angular Momentum of a Rigid Body

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of interacting particles such as a solid T-shaped handle. Let \(M=\sum_{i=1}^nm_i\) be the total mass of the particles, \(\bar{x}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the set of particles in the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\), \(p=\sum_{i=1}^np_i\) be the total linear momentum of the system of particles, \(f^e=\sum_{i=1}^n f_i^e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles, \(\pi =\sum_{i=1}^n\pi_i\) be the total angular momentum of the particles about a point \(O'\) fixed in the body, and \(\tau^e=\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-o)\times f_i^e\) be the resultant force moment of the external interactions acting on the particles about the point \(O'\) that is fixed in the body. Let the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) be such that it is fixed to the body and that its origin coincide with \(O'\). Let \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\) and \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) with respect to \(\mathbf{e}\). Also let \(\mathbb{I} \) be the moment of inertia tensor of the set of particles with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) with origin coinciding at \(O'\).

Then let \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}, \omega=R^T\Omega, \bar{X}=R^T(\bar{x}-o), \Pi=R^T\pi, T_e=R^T\tau_e\)

Show that the all of the following statements are true with respect to the total angular momentum of the set of particles about the point \(O'\).

  1. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +M\bar{X}\times R^T\dot{o}\right) \)

  2. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +M\bar{X}\times R^T\left(\frac{1}{M}p-R(\Omega\times \bar{X})\right)\right) \)

  3. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +\bar{X}\times R^Tp+M\bar{X}\times \bar{X} \times\Omega\right)\)

  4. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \(R\left(\mathbb{I}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2\right)R^T\omega+(\bar{x}-o)\times p\)

  5. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( (\mathbb{I}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2)\Omega +\bar{X}\times R^Tp \)

name.text: Free Rigid Body - Periodic Orbits - Sphere Ellipsoid

name.text: Angular Momentum of a Rigid Body

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of interacting particles such as a solid T-shaped handle. Let \(M=\sum_{i=1}^nm_i\) be the total mass of the particles, \(\bar{x}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the set of particles in the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\), \(p=\sum_{i=1}^np_i\) be the total linear momentum of the system of particles, \(f^e=\sum_{i=1}^n f_i^e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles, \(\pi =\sum_{i=1}^n\pi_i\) be the total angular momentum of the particles about a point \(O'\) fixed in the body, and \(\tau^e=\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-o)\times f_i^e\) be the resultant force moment of the external interactions acting on the particles about the point \(O'\) that is fixed in the body. Let the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) be such that it is fixed to the body and that its origin coincide with \(O'\). Let \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\) and \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) with respect to \(\mathbf{e}\). Also let \(\mathbb{I} \) be the moment of inertia tensor of the set of particles with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) with origin coinciding at \(O'\).

Then let \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}, \omega=R^T\Omega, \bar{X}=R^T(\bar{x}-o), \Pi=R^T\pi, T_e=R^T\tau_e\)

Which of the following statements are true about the angular momentum of the set of particles about the point \(O'\):

  1. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +M\bar{X}\times R^T\dot{o}\right) \)

  2. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +M\bar{X}\times R^T\left(\frac{1}{M}p-R(\Omega\times \bar{X})\right)\right) \)

  3. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( \left(\mathbb{I}\Omega +\bar{X}\times R^Tp+M\bar{X}\times \bar{X} \times\Omega\right)\)

  4. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \(R\left(\mathbb{I}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2\right)R^T\omega+(\bar{x}-o)\times p\)

  5. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( (\mathbb{I}+M\widehat{\bar{X}}^2)\Omega +\bar{X}\times R^Tp \)

name.text: Interacting Particle Equations in the spatial frame

questiontext.text:
Consider a set of interacting particles such as a water bubble. Let \(\mathbf{e}\) be an inertial frame and the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) be such that its origin is \(O'\) and \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\). Let \(M=\sum_{i=1}^nm_i\) be the total mass of the particles. With respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) let \(\bar{x}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the set of particles, \(p=\sum_{i=1}^np_i\) be the total linear momentum of the system of particles, \(f^e=\sum_{i=1}^n f_i^e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles, \(\pi =\sum_{i=1}^n\pi_i\) be the total angular momentum of the particles about the point \(O'\), and \(\tau^e=\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-o)\times f_i^e\) be the resultant force moment of the external interactions acting on the particles about \(O'\). Also let \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}, \bar{X}=R^T(\bar{x}-o), T_e=R^T\tau_e\)

Which of the following statements are true about the total rate of change of angular momentum of the set of particles about the point \(O'\):

  1. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( -M\dot{o}\times \dot{\bar{x}}+\tau_e \)

  2. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times \dot{\bar{X}}+T_e \)

  3. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( R\left(-MR^T\dot{o}\times (\Omega\times {\bar{X}}+\dot{\bar{X}})+T_e\right)\)

  4. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times R^T\dot{\bar{x}}+T_e \)

Consider a set of interacting particles such as a solid T-shaped handle. Let \(\mathbf{e}\) be an inertial frame and the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) be such that it is fixed with respect to the body and its origin is \(O'\). Let \(\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{e}R\) and \(o\) be the representation of \(O'\) with respect to \(\mathbf{e}\). Let \(M=\sum_{i=1}^nm_i\) be the total mass of the particles. With respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) let \(\bar{x}\) be the representation of the center of mass of the set of particles, \(p=\sum_{i=1}^np_i\) be the total linear momentum of the system of particles, \(f^e=\sum_{i=1}^n f_i^e\) be the total resultant of the external forces acting on the particles, \(\pi =\sum_{i=1}^n\pi_i\) be the total angular momentum of the particles about the point \(O'\), and \(\tau^e=\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-o)\times f_i^e\) be the resultant force moment of the external interactions acting on the particles about \(O'\). Also let \(\widehat{\Omega}=R^T\dot{R}, \bar{X}=R^T(\bar{x}-o),\Pi=R^T\pi, T_e=R^T\tau_e\)

Which of the following statements are true about the total rate of change of angular momentum of the set of particles about the point \(O'\):

  1. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( -M\dot{o}\times \dot{\bar{x}}+\tau_e \)

  2. with respect to the inertial frame \(\mathbf{e}\) it has the representation

    \( \omega \times (\bar{x}-o)\times p+\tau_e \)

  3. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega \times {\bar{X}}+T_e \)

  4. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \(\left(\mathbb{I}\dot{\Omega}-\mathbb{I}{\Omega}\times \Omega-MR^T\dot{o}\times \Omega\times \bar{X} +M\bar{X}\times R^T\ddot{o}\right)\)

    where \(\mathbb{I} \) is the moment of inertia tensor of the set of particles about \(O'\)

  5. with respect to the frame \(\mathbf{b}\) it has the representation

    \( -MR^T\dot{o}\times R^T\dot{\bar{x}}+T_e \)
